entry.et: Middle English tresorie, from Anglo-French, from tresor treasure

def.dt: :a place in which stores of wealth are kept
:the place of deposit and disbursement of collected funds
:one where public revenues are deposited, kept, and disbursed
:a governmental department in charge of finances and especially the collection, management, and expenditure of public revenues
:the building in which the business of such a governmental department is transacted
:a government security (as a note or bill) issued by the Treasury
:a repository for treasures a treasury of poems
:a currency note issued by the United States Treasury in payment for silver bullion purchased under the Sherman Silver Purchase Act of 1890
:a United States government bond usually with a maturity of not less than one year or more than seven years

:the superabundant satisfaction of Christ for human sins and the excess of merit of the saints which according to Roman Catholic theology is effective for salvation of others and is available for dispensation through indulgences
:issued stock reacquired by a corporation and held as an asset
